{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3610457,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T03:21:41.083Z","cooked":"

Does anyone know if the internal algorithms for pose estimation that run on Limelights are publicly available? I’ve been searching but have yet to find anything. I’m working on a little summer project right now to make improvements to the MegaTag 1/2 algorithms and wanted to see what level of optimizations/filters/features go on under the hood as a place to start.

No, limelight is closed sorce, but photonvision’s constrained PnP solver is extremely similar and the entier project is both open sorce and used by hundreds of teams.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-05-03T04:04:44.247Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":544,"readers_count":543,"score":108.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":501134,"topic_slug":"limelight-internals","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53160,"username":"RomanTechPlus","name":"Roman A.","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/romantechplus/{size}/214929_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/limelight-internals/501134/3","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3610532,"name":"Carlos Salazar","username":"StarbuckBarista","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starbuckbarista/{size}/186251_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T05:31:13.447Z","cooked":"

I’m going to jump in here and point out that Limelight doesn’t actually use a PnP algorithm to solve for robot poses on the field. Instead, it uses the other common method for AprilTags: a trigonometric algorithm.

PnP, or Perspective-n-Point, is a general-purpose computer vision technique that estimates an object’s pose by matching known 3D points (like the corners of an AprilTag) to their 2D projections in the camera image. It’s typically more flexible and accurate, especially when tags are viewed at steep angles or are partially occluded, but it’s also more computationally intensive and can introduce higher latency.

The trigonometric method, on the other hand, leverages the known square geometry of AprilTags and applies direct trigonometric relationships to estimate pose. It assumes the tag lies flat and that the camera is calibrated correctly. While it may not handle edge cases as well as PnP, it’s significantly faster and more lightweight, making it well-suited for real-time use on embedded systems like Limelight.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-05-03T05:31:13.447Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":507,"readers_count":506,"score":271.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":501134,"topic_slug":"limelight-internals","display_username":"Carlos Salazar","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":53160,"username":"RomanTechPlus","name":"Roman A.","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/romantechplus/{size}/214929_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming & Electrical Captain"},"post_url":"/t/limelight-internals/501134/4","custom_user_title":"Programming & Electrical Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"question","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3610561,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T11:11:26.154Z","cooked":"

So with some optimizations to the algorithm, based on a team’s use case, could you get a trigonometric solver to work at a higher accuracy level than PnP?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-05-03T11:11:26.154Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":413,"readers_count":412,"score":82.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":501134,"topic_slug":"limelight-internals","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57451,"username":"StarbuckBarista","name":"Carlos Salazar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starbuckbarista/{size}/186251_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/limelight-internals/501134/5","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3610628,"name":"Joe Ross","username":"Joe_Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T15:18:17.347Z","cooked":"
StarbuckBarista:

I’m going to jump in here and point out that Limelight doesn’t actually use a PnP algorithm to solve for robot poses on the field. Instead, it uses the other common method for AprilTags: a trigonometric algorithm.

What is your source? While it can use trigonometric, it can also use pnp. You can see several references to pnp in the limelight docs.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-05-03T15:18:17.347Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":374,"readers_count":373,"score":124.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":501134,"topic_slug":"limelight-internals","display_username":"Joe Ross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":65,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/limelight-internals/501134/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3610677,"name":"Geoffrey","username":"Geoffrey8814","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geoffrey8814/{size}/262430_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T17:07:46.318Z","cooked":"

I believe the general concept behind the Limelight is similar to what PV and other vision systems are doing. However, Limelight has distinct advantages in corner detection and pose filtering. While most vision systems in FRC rely on OpenCV ArUco detection(which is faster but less stable) Limelight’s corner detection is very stable and has an extremely low standard deviation.

One feature introduced in Limelight 3G or 3 is more reliable corner detection. The only library capable of achieving this is AprilTag3(or their custom library because they said “optimized apriltag detector”), which is slightly slower but offers much better stability. Additionally, the cable connecting the camera (OV9281) to the processor uses CSI, providing less compression and sharper edges than usb2.

Regarding the pose filter, the SolvePnP algorithm generates a list of possible positions sorted by re-projection error, based on my understanding. However, due to errors in corner detection, the re-projection error may not reflect the actual accuracy of the pose. For LL 4, they reportedly use an internal gyro and height (to my knowledge) along with re-projection error to determine the best robot pose, LL 3 and 3G utilized timestamps in NT to compensate for latency.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-05-03T17:12:40.551Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":340,"readers_count":339,"score":118.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":501134,"topic_slug":"limelight-internals","display_username":"Geoffrey","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60663,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limelight-internals/501134/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3610751,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T18:32:05.962Z","cooked":"

That makes sense. What I’m currently looking to do is use the corners already sent from a Limelight 3G over NetworkTables and creating my own solver that uses gyro readings and overcomes a couple shortcomings that I noticed this year (for example, trusting the pose info gained from closer tags a lot more than further tags, being able to have custom confidence levels for individual tags rather than throwing out tag infos entirely, and being able to use gyro information to disambiguate without entirely disregarding a measured angle to a tag) while also giving more flexibility for Rio-side adjustments on the fly. Do you think that the tradeoff of maybe losing some of the fine tuning and hidden optimizations that currently run on the Limelight would be worth it for tighter control over a couple smaller things?

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-05-03T18:32:05.962Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":279,"readers_count":278,"score":60.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":501134,"topic_slug":"limelight-internals","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60663,"username":"Geoffrey8814","name":"Geoffrey","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geoffrey8814/{size}/262430_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/limelight-internals/501134/8","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3610754,"name":"Carlos Salazar","username":"StarbuckBarista","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starbuckbarista/{size}/186251_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T18:35:17.316Z","cooked":"

I want to apologize for originally framing the discussion in black-and-white terms, specifically stating that Limelight “doesn’t use PnP.” That was an oversimplification and didn’t fully acknowledge the nuance of what’s likely going on under the hood, especially with the newer MegaTag2 pipeline.

Here’s a more informed breakdown:

  • Limelight’s single-tag detection pipeline, which outputs tx, ty, and ta, is built around direct angular and area measurements. This strongly aligns with trigonometric estimation, where the tag is assumed to lie on a flat plane at a known height. This approach is lightweight and fast—ideal for embedded systems—and likely served as the foundation for MT1, which appears to extend these calculations for full robot pose estimation.

  • However, MT1’s performance degrades at long distances or oblique angles, where trigonometric methods fall short. That’s why this GIF from the Limelight documentation showing MT1 vs MT2 at long range is so compelling: it clearly illustrates how MT1’s pose output becomes unstable or erratic, while MT2 (the red robot) remains far more accurate and stable.

  • These improvements, paired with Limelight’s description of MT2 as providing “excellent pose estimates given a single tag, no matter the perspective” and being “robust to physical AprilTag placement inaccuracies,” are strong indicators that MT2 uses a PnP-based or hybrid solver. These algorithms are built to handle perspective distortion, imperfect tag alignment, and smaller image sizes by minimizing reprojection error, not relying on strict geometric assumptions.

Thanks to @Joe_Ross for challenging my earlier statement. It’s clear that Limelight’s pipelines have evolved significantly, and MT2 likely represents a shift to more advanced vision algorithms that go beyond trigonometric shortcuts.

Em, I think LL is also using the PNP to figure out the angle of the tag, they use gyro to disambiguate. The problem you described might be latency or offset in gyro. Regarding the weight, I don’t think PNP will assign weight to each point. However, you can use algorithms like RANSAC which randomly sample corners and calculate the result using the sample with the lowest re-projection error to eliminate abnormal value.
In addition, I don’t think running advanced algorithms on roborio is a good idea due to its limited computational capabilities. I think LL provides programmable features using python. I haven’t tried that but I think it would be better than running algorithms on roborio especially since it has libraries such as OpenCV and numpy embedded.

I thought that the only computationally expensive part of vision was running the ML model

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-05-04T04:24:44.893Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":53.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":501134,"topic_slug":"limelight-internals","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60663,"username":"Geoffrey8814","name":"Geoffrey","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geoffrey8814/{size}/262430_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/limelight-internals/501134/13","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3611727,"name":"Geoffrey","username":"Geoffrey8814","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geoffrey8814/{size}/262430_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-04T06:00:53.794Z","cooked":"

Yeah, typically, these algorithms are not considered computationally expensive. However, since the RoboRIO has very limited computational power and is already running the robot’s code, these algorithms could interfere with the robot’s main thread. Additionally, performing linear algebra in Java can be inefficient, with poor memory access that may slow down the main thread without you even noticing. In contrast, jumpy and opencv run their code in c++ with many optimizations.

CakeDeer6:

computationally expensive part of vision

On a roboRIO v1 the WPILib detection of an AprilTag uses 40% of the CPU and the pose estimation uses another 40% - prohibitively expensive on a v1 and at least feasible to use on a v2.
